name: 1-Methyl-1-nitrosourea
Reason: The functional groups in 1-Methyl-1-nitrosourea and their likely contributions to the melting point are as follows: the urea group (NC(=O)NH2) is associated with strong hydrogen bonding, which typically increases melting point significantly; let's assign a baseline value of 132°C, which is the melting point of urea itself. The methyl group (CH3-) usually raises the melting point due to an increase in van der Waals interactions; let's assign +5°C for that. The nitroso (N=O) group usually has a moderate-to-little effect on melting point due to its electronegativity and size; we'll assign it a -5°C effect. The combination of these effects will allow us to predict the melting point of the compound.

name: 1-Methyl-1-nitrosourea

The overall prediction will take these effects into account.

name: 1-Methyl-1-nitrosourea
Reason:
To predict the melting point of 1-Methyl-1-nitrosourea, we will consider the functional groups present and their contribution to the melting point. The basic unit here could be urea, which has a melting point of about 133°C. The nitroso group tends to lower the melting point due to less efficient packing, we can estimate each nitroso group to reduce the melting point by about -20°C. A methyl group usually raises the melting point due to increased van der Waals forces; we can estimate each methyl group to add around +5°C. 1-Methyl-1-nitrosourea has one nitroso group and one methyl group. Thus: 
133°C (urea base) - 20°C (nitroso group) + 5°C (methyl group) = 118°C.
